block.p: Milosevic's Grip on Power Is Broken by Angry Serbs Hundreds of thousands of Serbs roamed Belgrade and occupied key buildings, bringing the 13-year reign of Slobodan Milosevic to the edge of collapse. Mr. Milosevic's whereabouts was unknown. Though the army stayed out of the fray, the chiefs of the security forces had yet to formally shift allegiance to Vojislav Kostunica, the opposition leader who claimed victory in the presidential election on Sept. 24.
President Clinton encouraged the crowds but made clear that American forces would not intervene.

Russian at India Nuclear Lab President Vladimir V. Putin took a tour of India's leading nuclear research center, where reactors and bombs are designed, and promised to work with India in developing peaceful uses for atomic energy.

Effort to Halt Mideast Violence Deadly clashes in Israel and the Palestinian territories slowed but did not stop, even as Palestinian and Israeli leaders issued orders to curb the violence and both sides continued American-brokered talks.

Lockerbie Diary Admitted The three judges conceded that a 1988 desk diary belonging to one of two Libyans on trial in the bombing of Pan Am Flight 103 had probably been seized illegally, but allowed it to be entered as evidence.

Tory Leader Sees Labor Demise William Hague told his party's convention that Conservatives now had broader appeal to the middle class than the New Labor philosophy of Prime Minister Tony Blair and were ready to run the country.

Irish Blood Inquiry An official inquiry into the infection of more than 200 Irish hemophiliacs with H.I.V. and hepatitis C has confirmed that the government's Blood Transfusion Service Board knowingly put them at risk in the 1980's.

U.N. Tribunal for Sierra Leone The United Nations Security Council got a blueprint for a war crimes tribunal for Sierra Leone, where children barely big enough to shoulder a weapon have been involved in a civil war marked by amputations and the terrorizing of villages.

Running Mates Take Stage In Vice Presidential Debate Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, the Democrats' choice for vice president, and Dick Cheney, the Republicans', met in Danville, Ky., for a calm and fluid debate on taxation, foreign policy and other issues.

Gore's Embellishments Republicans complained about the accuracy of several of Vice President Al Gore's statements in his debate with Gov. George W. Bush, and even some Democrats expressed puzzlement over Mr. Gore's repeated missteps in this regard.

Aftermath of Secrets Case Attorney General Janet Reno told a group of Asian-American leaders, whom she met with on Wednesday, that she would seek to make public a classified Justice Department review reported to be critical of the investigation and prosecution of Wen Ho Lee, the former Los Alamos scientist.

Chairman Faulted on Ethics The House ethics committee criticized Representative Bud Shuster, the Pennsylvania Republican who is chairman of the House Transportation Committee, for improper links with a lobbyist who once worked for him and for other misbehavior.

Moving Spending Legislation Congress began to hasten its pace in moving to approve a number of the remaining spending bills needed to keep the government functioning. Among actions taken during the day, House and Senate negotiators dropped a provision to make hate attacks on gays a federal crime.

Making Policy Dispute Personal House members have inserted a provision into an $80 billion agriculture spending bill that would strip the under secretary of agriculture for natural resources and the environment, James R. Lyons, of authority to supervise the Forest Service and the Natural Resources Conservation Service. Though Republicans support the provision, its author is a Democrat, Representative Marion Berry of Arkansas, who believes Mr. Lyons has not done enough for farmers fighting E.P.A. rules on runoff from farm land.

Mayor Assails U.S. Finding Of Profiling by Police Mayor Giuliani angrily defended the Police Department against a federal finding of racial profiling, saying a Justice Department investigation into police tactics was politically motivated and based on flawed analysis of stop-and-search statistics.

$3 Million for Police Beating A federal jury awarded $3 million to a Bronx woman, Irma Morales, 51, who said she was beaten by an undercover police officer after being mistakenly arrested in a drug case. The city said it would appeal.

Study Finds I.N.S. Abuses A study made available by the Lawyers Committee for Human Rights said federal immigration inspectors mistreated or turned away legal visitors as well as torture victims who might have credible claims to political asylum in the United States.

Dispute Over Lazio Ad Hillary Rodham Clinton's Senate campaign said Rick A. Lazio's campaign had violated an agreement barring ads paid for by outside groups by running an ad paid for by the Republican National Committee. The Lazio campaign said the ad, featuring disabled people, did not violate the pact. The Clinton campaign was considering how to respond.

Mapping the Mouse The National Institutes of Health and others said they would spend $58 million to decode the genome of the mouse by February 2001, to use as a guide for interpreting the human genome sequence now in hand.

Revised Dietary Guidelines The American Heart Association said people should focus on the kinds of foods they eat rather than the percentages of fat or nutrients. For the first time, two weekly servings of fatty fish (three ounces) like tuna or salmon are advised.

Setback for Priceline The online bidding service dropped a feature that let consumers bid for groceries and gasoline, citing financial reasons. Investors stand to lose most of the $360 million they put into the venture, the Priceline WebHouse Club, a private affiliate of the publicly traded Priceline.

Auction Ex-Chief Pleads Guilty Diana D. Brooks, a former top executive of Sotheby's, pleaded guilty to fixing commissions with a rival house, Christie's. She said she was following the orders of A. Alfred Taubman, Sotheby's former chairman, who denied the accusations.
Music Deal Withdrawn Time Warner and the EMI Music Group of Britain withdrew their application for a $20 billion joint venture to link their music businesses and will develop a revised plan.
Mets Pull Even in San Francisco The Mets beat the Giants, 5-4, in Game 2 of their series. St. Louis beat Atlanta, 10-4, to go up, 2-0.
